entry.summary: So far, at least, System Integrity Protect (‚Äúrootless‚Äù mode) is causing quite a mess on the El Capitan betas. I‚Äôm sure Apple will get it straightened out‚Ä¶ and I‚Äôm hoping it‚Äôs by the next public beta.
Very interesting: Bartender works with System Integrity Protection‚Ä¶ if you disable it, then reenable it. Details here.

Hey, Google, I know I keep telling you this, but you don‚Äôt seem to be listening. If I put a search term in the box, I actually want it in my results. I know you think your algorithm is smarter than me. But it isn‚Äôt.
I‚Äôve now migrated all my chriskrycho.com emails to Fastmail. Still have some organizing to do, but I‚Äôm no longer tied to Google Apps there. Just a few more addresses to migrate‚Ä¶

Whoa! After years of demand, Confluence finally added support for importing Markdown-formatted content in its ‚ÄúMarkup‚Äù box. It‚Äôs not native support for editing in Markdown‚Ä¶ but it is a step forward. Good work, Atlassian.
Just recorded the first episode of a new, short, weekly podcast I‚Äôm working on. Audio should be live in about a week!

I started looking into bespoke publishers for that blog-post-book idea. First one I found has this for a logo:

Yes, that is Comic Sans. Immediately filed under nope nope nope.
I think‚Äîso I can have a hard copy‚ÄîI may start printing a nicely typeset of my blog posts each year.

People often point to this (hilariously accurate) flowchart to explain how to solve tech problems‚Ä¶ but it leaves something really important out: we ‚Äútechies‚Äù know the right questions to ask. That makes a big difference.
Another little feature of Rust I quite like: the use of traits instead of inheritance to share behavior. All the benefits of inheritance, and a few more besides, but none of the drawbacks.
If you‚Äôre running Windows 10, you should be aware of its defaults with sharing WiFi passwords, and know how to change them.

An advantage to running Windows 10 in a VM: this boondoggle isn‚Äôt a problem for me, because as far as that VM is concerned, it‚Äôs talking over an ethernet connection and doesn‚Äôt have any idea there‚Äôs a WiFi network involved.
On a semi-related note to the previous post‚Ä¶ I love the new option to hide and show the menubar automatically on non-full-screen views in OS X 10.11.
El Cap public beta 2 was all sorts of broken. Things like copy and paste weren‚Äôt working right! Beta 3 looks much better so far.
I just realized that one of the reason Rust so strongly appeals to me is that its design embodies one of my favorite traits from the Zen of Python: explicit is better than implicit.

Courtesy of something in my stack not playing right, I‚Äôve now been reduced to pushing and pulling changes between OS X and my Windows VM through Bitbucket, rather than just having a mapped drive locally. This feels silly.
Per @manton‚Äôs suggestion, I‚Äôve set up IFTTT recipes for ADN and Twitter to repost microblog posts from my own blog to those services. If you see this post either place, it worked.
Hmm, this may be telling of the future‚Ä¶ SourceTree now introduces itself as a Git tool. No mention of Hg at all. üòü

I did something new with the paper I just published: I used BibTeX and pandoc to generate the citations in it automatically. I‚Äôm delighted at the result. In the next few days, I‚Äôll write up a short post on how I did it, because it‚Äôs very handy for academics.
I can feel my motivation on this paper dropping by the hour. Must. finish. it.
So‚Ä¶ Apple Music is going to have some serious issues if it can‚Äôt get ‚Äúplaying music on demand‚Äù separate from iTunes store issues.
Pro tip: it turns out that generic versions of psychotropic medications may not be as effective as the brand-name version. Lessons we‚Äôve learned the hard way in the last two months.
One of the things that impresses me most about the new DayOne sync is how blazingly fast it is. Changes are nearly instantaneous.

Me: I‚Äôm really delighted by the big girl you‚Äôre growing into, Ellie, and I love you so much!
Ellie: I really love my magazine!

Woke up to my alarm with my head feeling stuffed with gauze, went back to sleep, woke up with my wife‚Äôs alarm to find the room spinning, went back to sleep, woke up to just a plain headache. Rough start to the week‚Ä¶

Trying to delete an Amazon account.

Good grief, this is a labyrinthine process.

Just one more reason to dislike this company.
How in the world have I gone all this time and never listened to Krzysztof Penderecki before today? This is outstanding stuff.

My dear wife has started teaching herself Python as a hobby. She has the essential skill required to succeed as a programmer: the willingness to persevere even when it isn‚Äôt making sense to her. I‚Äôm extremely impressed.

That time when I accidentally deleted my ‚Äúdev-tools‚Äù folder in /Applications.

I‚Äôm grateful for Time Machine right now.
A wished-for future Apple laptop lineup: 12- and 14-inch MacBooks, 13- and 15-inch MacBook Pros. I‚Äôd do a 14-inch MacBook and a retina iMac as my remote/at-home combo in a heartbeat.

I want so much to grind some of this single-origin decaf coffee and drink it right now.

But my 1-year-old is asleep downstairs.

So: nope.
Trying to decide whether the kind of ‚Äúnot good‚Äù I‚Äôm feeling today is the kind that will get better or worse with exercise.
Playing with CSS transforms and transitions while I listen to a lecture on Romans for my New Testament class. Keep myself awake‚Ä¶
Found a new use for Rogue Amoeba‚Äôs Audio Hijack: boosting audio from too-quiet vidoes. Sweet.
Working on an essay on theological anthropology. The introduction alone is 650 words long‚Ä¶
I cannot wait till I can switch to ES2015. Got bit by the stupid var scoping issue again. You‚Äôd think I‚Äôd be past that by now‚Ä¶

Reading JavaScript Allong√©. Just got to combinatorial logic (kestrel and idiot bird, for those in the know). Then he destructured a list with them.

Mind. Blown.

One of the things that annoys me most when writing C is how difficult (really, almost impossible) it is to do anything generically. The same operation for different items in a struct? Good luck. It‚Äôs possible, but rarely worth the work.

I heard someone suggest that even if the subordination of the Son in the Trinity isn‚Äôt expressly taught, it‚Äôs useful in debates, so why not?

Besides the fact that I think the idea is contrary to Scripture, we should never reduce the Triune I Am to mere means to other ends.

Q: What is the chief end of man?
A: To love work and be as efficient as possible in every task.

‚Äîthe first question in the Western Technocratic Catechism

Depression is an awful, awful part of our fallen existence. I‚Äôd do almost anything to take that darkness away from my wife.

God has grace for us in the meantime. But we‚Äôre ready for resurrection bodies with healed brains.

‚ÄúCome, Lord Jesus!‚Äù ‚ÄîRevelation 22:20

Finally giving FontStand a try.

Holy wow. This is a great tool‚Äîgood software, good business plan.
It‚Äôs 96¬∞ out, it feels like 105¬∞, and it is about 50% relative humidity. I got sweaty walking to and from my car. Gross.

I‚Äôve been using Cardo as the typeface for theology posts for the last month or so; I‚Äôm thinking about switching again. The barrier? Greek and Hebrew support. Because of how font-family and font-loading work, I may be able to get away with adding a custom font for them, though.
The Counter Culture Finca Al Puente Honduran I ground for my Chemex this morning was amazing‚Äîone of the best cups of coffee I‚Äôve ever had.

Well, tonight I seem to have finished my journey from the dispensationalist premillennialism I grew up in through the historic premillennial view I‚Äôve held for the last few years into amillennialism.

To my great delight, and thanks to a suggestion from App.net friend @jnm, I was able to get a static copy of my 2012‚Äì2013-era site archived this evening. That in turn means I‚Äôll be able to replace my WordPress install with static HTML pages over the next few weeks. Victory.

I have been using a small notebook to jot down ideas and thoughts as they come to me the last few weeks. It‚Äôs funny, but I can almost physically feel them flipping different switches in my brain as I write with pencil and paper rather than tapping on a screen. Medium matters.
Kate kept us up late last night (no idea why). And we ran out of coffee yesterday. It‚Äôs going to be a long day‚Ä¶
Our youngest has been sleeping through the night for a week now. Going to bed at 9:45 & getting up at 5:15 is suddenly doable again. Huzzah!
If, in your discussion of eschatology, you skip or glide over physical resurrection, you have missed Christian hope almost entirely.

I‚Äôm reading Life Everlasting, and reminded again just how much form matters. This is heady stuff, but the authors (or their editors) seem incapable of rising above a dry recitation of the facts. It undercuts everything they say.

Tip: if you‚Äôre using Mercurial‚Äôs bookmarks to track lightweight branches, somewhat analogous to Git‚Äôs branches, use Mercurial‚Äôs special @ tag to track whatever you want to treat as the tip of a master branch. That way, any clone will check that out by default.

Thinking about how to structure the content on my blog. Layout, categories, etc. I think the problem is insufficient clarity about data hierarchy‚Äîa lack of understanding about how the pieces relate to each other. I‚Äôll keep working on it.

I just taught Jaimie how to use GitHub for Mac (as she is helping a friend with his Jekyll-powered website), and explained the basics of distributed version control. She is totally a boss. And GitHub for Mac is a pretty good app.
I was inspired by the release of Tweetbot 2 for Mac to finally try seeing what utility I can wrangle out of lists. I think it‚Äôll be a win.
I just discovered that Jason Snell and John Siracusa are actually doing Robot or Not. I‚Äôm ridiculously excited.
I officially understand why people like triathlons. Cycling after running is just fine. Running after cycling is amazing.
In ‚ÄúWeb Decay Graph‚Äù, Tim Bray says pretty much exactly what Stephen and I said on Winning Slowly last year. Probably the first and only time we‚Äôll ever ‚Äúscoop‚Äù the rest of the internet.
Ugh. I‚Äôve spent an hour searching for an Evernote replacement, and my conclusion is: I‚Äôm going to end up using flat text files and grep.

I think I‚Äôm going to give up on Evernote again. UI problems left and right.

So‚Ä¶ what‚Äôs a good taggable, hierarchical, searchable notes app?

One of the tricks as I‚Äôm trying to work out what I want to do with Evernote: I have a bunch of old Evernote I want to pull in, but I am intentionally starting fresh. Now I have to decide how to bring that content over, especially as regards its tags, etc‚Ä¶

I am slowly working out a system for using Evernote to manage notes, books to read, etc. I have tried this before, but failed to think carefully enough about how to organize my system. Hopefully this time will work out better!
Found my wallet! After I ordered replacement debit and credit cards and driver‚Äôs license, of course. (It was in the back of Jaimie‚Äôs 2nd-grade Sunday School teaching binder‚Ä¶)
Wait, what‚Äôs that? The sound of an update to the about page, and one that includes a picture, for the first time since I relaunched this site using Pelican instead of WordPress? Can it be?
I‚Äôm listening to lectures on theology‚Ä¶ at double speed. It‚Äôs surprisingly comprehensible even at that pace, and getting through the material in half the time is no joke.
In the process of replacing my wallet and all of its contents: driver‚Äôs license, credit and debit cards, etc. Not my idea of a good time, to say the least.

One of (many) irritations with using Angular: every search turns up Bootstrap solutions.

I‚Äôm not using Bootstrap.

:sigh:

Question:

Why do we need to model the world using abstractions invented for pencil and paper? Can we solve quantitative problems without manipulating symbols?

Answer: exploring new approaches like this is great‚Äîbut throwing out patterns that have worked for millennia is‚Ä¶ unwise.

Neat! I just created a simple workflow in Workflows on my iPhone, which lets me generate new posts like this on the fly. I‚Äôm hoping to get to a point where I can even auto-publish with it‚Ä¶ but that‚Äôll be a while.

Every time I watch the kids at FBC Durham during out ‚ÄúExtended Session‚Äù‚Äîour main service childcare session‚ÄîI get sick. Take it as a mark of my love for you, saints of FBC, that I keep doing it anyway.

That project I started on the other day? It‚Äôs still going‚Ä¶ and swimmingly. I‚Äôve now gotten it not only working at the most basic level (as it was before) but also to do a bit more complex work. You can see it (and any other scripts I build) here.

I‚Äôve come to the conclusion that I really need to find a good way to organize links, notes, etc. for later reference. I‚Äôve tried Evernote before, and didn‚Äôt love it, but I don‚Äôt know of anything better. Time to try it again, maybe with a different approach this time, I suppose?
Every once in a while, I get frustrated with doing all my website stuff a bit more manually using Pelican. But then I remember the dark days, of WordPress, and I don‚Äôt regret the switch a bit.

Currently on my mind: how to chunk up the Bible text with semantic blobs and chapter/verse trees in corresponding data structures, in order to present meaningful sections of content (paragraphs, etc.) without resorting to delivering a whole book.
This post brought to you by a brand new script, which automatically generates the file needed‚ÄîYAML header and all!‚Äîto create a new microblog post on chriskrycho.com. Python for the win.
If you‚Äôre not using a password manager, today‚Äôs the day to start. And hey, look! 1Password has a 30% sale on!
I‚Äôve only been using tmux for about a week. I can‚Äôt even imagine trying to work without it anymore.
That time I misread a quiz time on Moodle and thought it closed at 12:05 am tonight‚Ä¶ but that‚Äôs when it opens. :sigh:

A friend of my complimented me tonight, describing me as ‚Äúintelligent and articulate.‚Äù I appreciated and accepted the compliment, but it struck me later: good as those things are, they are not the same as ‚Äúwise‚Äù or ‚ÄúGodly‚Äù‚Äîand those are what is necessary to teach well.

On the one hand, I really enjoy (many of) my seminary classes. On the other hand, having no time at all off between the end of my Spring semester and the beginning of the summer semester makes me want to be done with my M. Div.

Updated the websites today. Did a bunch of back end work that should be basically invisible or make a change seamlessly on the front end for both chriskrycho.com and winningslowly.org. Very satisfying day; nice to be working on things just because I can.
Microsoft Visual Studio: bringing you links in error messages‚Ä¶ that aren‚Äôt clickable!

I‚Äôm doing Project Euler with Elixir as a way of keeping myself sane while I try to get a project that worked fine in Visual Studio 2015 Technical Preview to build in Visual Studio 2015 Release Candidate. sigh

Current status: buried in the weeds of extern "C" and DLL linkage.

Let‚Äôs just say I‚Äôm looking forward to finishing this part and getting back to the bits where I actually make awesome things instead of just fighting with the tools.

One of the small joys of running my site through GitHub Pages is that you can trivially see the entire history of this site since I started doing it this way: just check out gh-pages at a date. I‚Äôm especially mindful of that for future archaeology, as I‚Äôm tweaking it right now.

The screen on Jaimie‚Äôs Kindle Keyboard cracked. Now we have to figure out what we‚Äôre going to do to replace it‚Ä¶ and since we‚Äôve basically sworn off of Amazon (a story for another day), I guess it‚Äôs time to start evaluating other ereader options.

There are things I want to do with my website that I just can‚Äôt do effectively in Pelican (like art-directed, multi-part presentations of certain content), and which were even worse with WordPress (which I loathe). I basically need a bespoke CMS to do everything I want. Alas.

A major irritation of writing Hebrew papers in Word: unlike every other tool on my Mac, Word does not properly transition between left-to-right and right-to-left languages. I have to type the Hebrew letters in left-to-right order. Argh.

I‚Äôve officially migrated the management of my Pelican environment (with which I build my blog) from virtualenvwrapper to pyenv. And I love it. Next up: the two remaining virtualenvwrapper environments I have.
What I want‚Äîwhat I really, really want‚Äîis the text and layout of the BHQ and NA28, sans apparatus, in a single binding, to use for my devotional reading.
7 pages of this paper, down. 13 to go. This is going quickly‚Äîthe advantage of having done lots of good preparatory research work.

I‚Äôve been tweaking things on this site a bit as part of my plan to freshen it up and make it more in line with my desires (and also to take a break from working on this crazy Hebrew paper‚Ä¶). I‚Äôm happy with the progress and changes I‚Äôve made.
Ugh. Nothing like being up sick half the night (throwing up etc.) to start the busiest week of the semester.

This paper requires that I cite 4 commentaries; I have notes from 9 so far. I need to write ~5,500‚Äì6,000 words; I have ~6,750 words of notes so far.

I need to stop reading articles and commentaries soon‚Ä¶
Downside: our girls both got up at 6:30 on a Saturday morning. Upside: they both slept through the night. I think I‚Äôll take that over/under.

Yet again, Atlassian demonstrates that they couldn‚Äôt care less what their customers actually want‚Äîat least, the small business customers like me. Adios. (Sadly, because I like Mercurial, but I‚Äôll take Git with GitHub/Gitlab.)

I‚Äôve been playing with pyenv. I think I‚Äôm sold. By which I mean: ‚ÄúHow long will it take me to convert from doing things with Homebrew and virtualenvwrapper to pure pyenv?‚Äù The answer is: I should wait till I finish my 20-page Hebrew exegetical paper.
It is simultaneously exciting and unnerving when you see something delightful while doing exegesis on a passage‚Ä¶ and none of the commentators see it.
I have flown a lot (for me) lately; it has been both wonderful and terrible. I love seeing different places; I hate being away from my family.
If you‚Äôre in a meeting and you know there‚Äôs a fight to win, fight that one as hard as you have to‚Ä¶ and let every other, less important thing go.

People who edit podcasts take different tacks on this, but for Winning Slowly, I happily shift around interactions, cut ‚Äúuhhs‚Äù, and generally improve the sound. My goal is for the show to be clear, not for it to be exactly what we recorded.
Dear TSA, allow me to resolve your worry that ‚Äúit could technically be anything in that water bottle‚Äù‚Äîby drinking from it.

For a class this year, I had to subscribe to a Baptist state paper. I picked the North Carolina paper, the Biblical Recorder. The experience of the ‚Äúdigital paper‚Äù is awful. It‚Äôs basically scans in a copy-protected container‚Äîas un-web-native as can be. These things need to improve, or they‚Äôll die in the next generation.
